prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: From the APEX observations of the N2H+(3-2) line (Fig. 2, right panel), all clumps but 16435-C3 have peak intensity (in T_MB) >0.3 K, corresponding to a peak flux of ~9.5 Jy. Given the high critical density of the line (see Sect. 1 of the Scientific Justification), the ALMA simulations shown in in Fig. 1 (panels (c) and (d)), and previous observations of this line in other high-mass star forming regions (e.g. Fontani et al. 2008, Zinchenko et al. 2013), we can reasonably assume that the total emission will fill an area of maximum angular diameter ~3-4'', distributed either in multiple low-mass cores (mu=130 case), or a single core with an extended envelope (mu=2 case). For a uniform core extended by 3-4'', the flux in a 0.3'' beam will be 9.5x(0.3/4)^2=0.05 Jy. The 1 sigma rms which can be achieved after 20 minutes of integration on source, assuming source declination of -50deg, dual polarisation, a velocity resolution of 0.13 km/s (smaller than the expected thermal intrinsic FWHM of the line, i.e. 0.14 km/s at T~15 K) and a water vapour column density of 1.26 mm, is ~0.012 Jy at 279.5 GHz. This implies a S/N ratio larger than 4 in all clumps. We stress that these are conservative lower limits and thus we are confident to detect the lines with much better S/N. With such integration time, the 1sigma rms that we will achieve in the continuum assuming a ~2GHz band, in dual polarisation mode, is 0.09 mJy. At a representative distance of ~4 kpc, assuming that the dust temperature equals the gas temperature (~15 K), one can derive the expected mass sensitivity under the same assumptions as in Beltran et al. (2006, i.e. gas-to-dust ratio of 100, dust mass opacity coefficient at 250 GHz = 1 cm^2 g^-1, and beta=2): a point-source of 0.27 mJy (3 sigma rms) corresponds to a mass of 0.07 M_sun. This guarantees that our observations will be sensitive to the very low-mass cores expected in the 'highly-fragmented' scenario.

We will use a 117 MHz Baseband-1 (~126 km/s at 279 GHz, much larger than the line full width at zero intensity) to cover the N2H+(3-2) line with dual polarisation and 61 kHz spectral resolution (~0.065 km/s), and a 2 GHz Baseband-2 (dual polarisation) to image the continuum. Baseband-3 will be used to cover the DCO+(4-3) and DCN(4-3) transitions, which have critial densities similar to that of the N2H+(3-2) and are useful tracers of deuteration, a key chemical parameter expected to be boosted in environments with significant depletion of CO (e.g. Robert & Millar 2000, A&A, 364, 780).

We propose to obtain single-field maps in both N2H+ (3-2) at and 279.512 GHz (band-7) and continuum towards the 11 clumps in Table~1 of the scientific justification in the C36-4 configuration. This configuration is a good compromise between angular resolution (~0.27'' at 278 GHz, i.e. ~1000 AU at 3.5 kpc) and sensitivity to possible extended structures of ~3'', which is the size of the fragmenting region as the ALMA simulations in Fig. 1 (panels (c) and (d)) show

Based on the simulations, the overall size of the fragmenting region is about 3-4''. However, because the extension of the envelope in which the fragments form is unknown so far but potentially more extended than this, we request additional ACA observations as a plus to help the interpretation of the higher-angular resolution data, which could be influenced by the extension and the dynamical state of the envelope itself (see the Scientific Justification)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This is the resubmission of project 2012.1.00366.S, approved in cycle-1, postponed to cycle-2, but not observed yet. The project aims at determining the population of dense cores (size, number, spatial distribution) embedded in 11 carefully selected massive clumps through high-angular resolution observations of N2H+ (3-2) and (sub-)mm continuum, in order to test high-mass star formation competing theories. High-mass stars are born from the gravitational collapse of such clumps (i) either via competitive accretion in highly fragmented clumps (ii) or through accretion onto single cores if fragmentation is suppressed. Simulations show that the fragmentation process is efficiently inhibited if a strong magnetic support dominates the dynamics during collapse. Vice-versa, a faint magnetic support favours the formation of many small fragments. Therefore, if the magnetic support dominates over turbulence in the formation of massive stars, we expect a majority of clumps with low fragmentation levels, and vice-versa.
